lexUnit.name: crucial.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: decisive or critical, especially in the success or failure of something

sentence.text: He also challenged the central premise of the service chiefs ' and Bevin 's argument : the belief that the Mediterranean was absolutely crucial to Britain s international position .
It 's important in small conferences where there are limited numbers moving slowly , but for bigger events it 's absolutely crucial .
It is absolutely crucial to the lives of the small creatures that the rock is returned precisely where it was found .
Sir Hector said : ` It 's absolutely crucial to dairy farmers and the industry that we have a scheme up and running by April 1994 which is acceptable . "
The most crucial factor to have emerged from the recent research into language learning is not what language the learners are exposed to but what the learner does with the language .
That seemed the most crucial question .

In general , fire is the crucial factor in life and the generation of life .

There 's no use in running out of money at the crucial moment . "

A HUGE Tory row today broke out after the government won the crucial Maastricht debate by just three votes .

The distinction between fixtures and fittings is crucial whenever a freehold or leasehold estate is sold to another .

They remain crucial to the United Left 's chances of electoral success .

Clearly the interrogator saw Mr Graham 's walking habits as being crucial to the case .

The annual report and accounts are crucial in communicating a company 's image .

The five-year-old child , treated in Italy , lacks an enzyme crucial to providing protection against common infections .
